stem: The nurse is inserting a Foley catheter in a male client. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Inflate the balloon and pull back gently until resistance is felt.
Position the client supine with legs slightly abducted and set up the sterile field.
Advance the catheter to the bifurcation of the 'Y' port.
Apply lubricant to the first 5-7 inches of the catheter and insert into the urethra.
Cleanse the meatus using circular motions from the center to the outside using antiseptic swabs.

rationale.correct: Male catheterization requires specific structural considerations. (1) Prep. (2) Circle cleansing is the standard for the glans. (3) Longer lubricant/insertion path for males. (4) For MALES, you must advance to the bifurcation (all the way) to ensure the balloon is in the bladder before inflation; inflating in the prostatic urethra is traumatic. (5) Seal.
rationale.incorrect: Advancing only until 'urine is seen' and then inflating is a risk for males; the long urethra means the balloon could still be in the tube, not the bladder.
clinicalPearls: If resistance is felt at the prostate, have the client take deep breaths and apply gentle, steady pressure. Do not force.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Bifurcation = Safe' for males. If you inflate when you first see urine, you might pop the balloon in the penis.

reviewUnits.heading: Principles of Urinary Catheterization
reviewUnits.body: Nurses maintain the drainage bag below the level of the bladder and avoid kinks in the tubing to prevent stasis and infection.
